children.name: Mountains
children.definition: used as part of a name for a group of mountains: vùng núi
examples: the Blue Ridge Mountains of Virginia

children.name: mountain
children.definition: a very high hill: núi
examples: the highest mountain in Austria
mountain aira walk in the clear mountain air

children.name: high
examples: These mountains are much higher than any in Europe.

children.name: rugged mountains
children.definition: rough and uneven
examples: the spectacular scenery of rugged mountains

children.name: a snow-capped mountain
children.definition: with snow on the top
examples: beautiful views of snow-capped mountains

children.name: a distant mountain
children.definition: far away
examples: The sun was setting over the distant mountains.

children.name: a great mountain
children.definition: a high, impressive mountain
examples: Here, great mountains are all around.

children.name: a sacred mountain
children.definition: considered holy
examples: Mount Fuji is a sacred mountain.

children.name: go/walk up a mountain
children.definition: alsoascend a mountainformal
examples: Carrie and Albert went up the mountain, neither of them speaking as they climbed.

children.name: climb a mountain
children.definition: walk and/or climb to the top of a mountain
examples: Hillary had climbed all the big mountains in New Zealand.

children.name: go/walk down a mountain
examples: She lost her way as she went down the mountain.

children.name: cross the mountains
examples: We crossed the mountains between Spain and France.

children.name: mountains rise
children.definition: go high into the sky
examples: The mountains rise above the plains.

children.name: moutains soar/towerliterary
children.definition: go very high into the sky
examples: The distant mountains soar abruptly towards the sky.

children.name: a mountain range/chain
children.definition: a number of mountains in a line
examples: The Alps are the largest mountain range in Europe.

children.name: a mountain top
examples: Until the end of June you may find snow on the mountain tops.

children.name: a mountain peak
children.definition: the top of a mountain
examples: Clouds hid the mountain peaks.

children.name: a mountain slope
children.definition: the sides of a mountain
examples: Snow lay on the steep mountain slopes.

children.name: a mountain pass
children.definition: a path or road between mountains
examples: Their journey took them through river valleys and over mountain passes.

children.name: a mountain stream
examples: The water was as clear and cold as a mountain stream.

children.name: mountain rescue
children.definition: people who help people who are in difficulty on a mountain
examples: Mountain rescue teams were called out to search for the missing climbers.

children.name: the top of a mountain
children.definition: alsothe summit of a mountainformal
examples: We climbed to the top of the mountain.

children.name: the foot of a mountain
children.definition: the bottom of a mountain
examples: We’ll take the car to the foot of the mountain and walk from there.

children.name: the side of a mountain
examples: The path wound up the side of the mountain.

children.name: Mount
children.definition: (written abbMt)  used in the names of mountains.
examples: Mount Fuji/ Mount Everest (Don’t say ‘Fuji Mountain)

children.name: peak
children.definition: a mountain: đỉnh; chỏm; ngọn núi
examples: Mount McKinley is Alaska’s highest peak.
It is one of the most difficult peaks to climb.
the highest peakMount McKinley is Alaska’s highest peak.

children.name: an area that have a lot of mountains or hills
hilly
children.definition: having a lot of hills: có nhiều đồi
examples: hilly region/area/terrain etc
a hilly area

children.name: highlands
children.definition: a mountainous area of a country→ lowlands: vùng cao, cao nguyên
examples: Most villages in the highlands are now connected by roads.
forested highlands
highland[attri adj] in or relating to an area with mountains or hills
highland springs

children.name: mountainous
children.definition: having a lot of mountains: có nhiều núi
examples: the mountainous coast of Wales
a mountainous region

children.name: with lots of hills or mountains
hilly
children.definition: an area of land that is hilly has lots of hills: lồi lõm

children.name: the hilly farmlands of New Jersey
examples: The vineyards are hilly and difficult to cultivate.

children.name: rolling hills/fields/farmland etc
children.definition: with a lot of rounded, not very steep hills and valleys, especially when this looks attractive: “cuồn cuộn”
examples: The castle is set in rolling hills to the north of Orvieto.
He stood at the top of the hill, admiring the rolling landscape.

children.name: mountainous
children.definition: an area of land that is mountainous has lots of high mountains: chập chùng
examples: The mainland of Greece is mountainous and largely infertile.
Fog and rain are common in the mountainous regions near the border.

children.name: hillside
children.definition: the sloping surface of a hill, rather than the level surface at the top of it: sườn đồi

children.name: hilltop
children.definition: the top part of a hill, rather than its sloping sides: đỉnh đồi

children.name: ridge
children.definition: a long narrow area of high ground, especially at the top of a mountain: rặngnúi
examples: I could see a group of climbers high up on a ridge.
We walked along the narrow mountain ridge.
figurativeA ridge (= narrow area) of high pressure will bring good weather this afternoon.

children.name: caldera
children.definition: a very large circular hollow that remains when the central part of a volcano falls in after an eruption: lòng chảo

children.name: mountainside
children.definition: the side or slope of a mountain: sườn núi
examples: Can you see those goats high uponthe mountainside?

children.name: mountaintop
children.definition: the top of a mountain: đỉnh núi

children.name: peak
children.definition: the sharply pointed top of a mountain: đỉnh; chỏm; ngọn núi
examples: snow-cappedmountain peks
jagged peaks

children.name: a mountain peak
examples: All around are the spectacular mountain peaks of the Jungfrau region.

children.name: a snowy/snow-capped peak
examples: The snow-capped peaks of the Sorondo mountain range provide a dramatic backdrop.

children.name: a jagged peak
children.definition: with several sharp points
examples: At first all I could see was the hazy black outline of a jagged peak.

children.name: a rocky peak
examples: The Castle is situated on a rocky peak.

children.name: a distant peak
examples: The mist cleared to reveal the distant peaks across the valley.

children.name: summit
children.definition: the highest point of a mountain: đỉnh, chỏm, chóp, ngọn
examples: On this day in 1784, Dr Michel Paccard and Jacques Balmatreachedthe summit of Mont Blanc.

children.name: summit of
examples: Many people have now reached the summit of Mount Everest.

children.name: clifftop
children.definition: an area of ground at the top of a cliff
examples: We stayed in a marvellous clifftop hotel.

children.name: foothills
children.definition: a group of smaller hills below a range of high mountains: vùngđồi thấp
examples: the foothills of thePyrenees
the Sierra foothills

children.name: hill
children.definition: an area of land that is higher than the surrounding land: đồi
examples: Hills are not as high as mountains.
Their house is on a hill overlooking the sea.
A cart was making its way up the hill.

children.name: steep
examples: She pushed her bicycle up the steep hill.

children.name: rolling/gentle hills
children.definition: hills with slopes that are not steep
examples: He loved the green rolling hills of Dorset.

children.name: a long hill
examples: The bus started going up the long hill into town.

children.name: climb a hill
children.definition: walk or drive up a hill
examples: She climbed the hill out of the village.

children.name: go down a hill
examples: It's best to use a low gear when you are going down steep hills.

children.name: the top of a hill
examples: The view from the top of the hill was beautiful.

children.name: the brow/crest of a hill
children.definition: the top part of a hill
examples: A tank appeared over the brow of the hill.

children.name: the bottom/foot of a hill
examples: The house was at the bottom of a hill.

children.name: hill country
children.definition: a rural area where there are a lot of hills
examples: the rough hill country on the Welsh border

children.name: a hill townthe hill towns of Tuscany
knoll
children.definition: a small low hill with a rounded top: gò
examples: a grassy knoll

children.name: crag
children.definition: a high rough mass of rock which sticks out from the land around it: vách đá cheo leo
examples: An eagle sailed over the high crags.

children.name: precipice
children.definition: a very steep side of a cliff or a mountain: vách đứng
examples: The film opens with a shot of a climber dangling from a precipice.
They were standing on the edge of a precipice.

children.name: range
children.definition: a group of hills or mountainsarranged in a line: dãy (núi, đồi..)
examples: the mountain range that is part of the border between Norway and Sweden
the Pennine Range
a land of highmountain rangesand deep valleys
range of mountains/hills
the longest range of hills in the Lake District
We could see a low rangeofhills in the distance.

children.name: cliff
children.definition: a high area of rock with a very steep side, often on a coast vách đá (nhô ra biển)
examples: Keep away from the edge of the cliff - you might fall.

children.name: high/low
examples: The cliffs here are the highest in Britain.

children.name: steep
children.definition: sloping at a high angle
examples: The cliffs were steep and dangerous.

children.name: a sheer/vertical cliff
children.definition: straight up and down rather than sloping
examples: Sheer cliffs defend the island.

children.name: a sea cliff
examples: The birds breed mainly on sea cliffs and in sea caves.

children.name: a coastal cliff
examples: Here the coastal cliffs are low, jutting out into the sea.

children.name: a rocky cliff
examples: The forest stops where a rocky cliff falls to a saltwater lagoon.

children.name: a craggy/jagged cliff
children.definition: with a lot of sharp rocks
examples: This is an area of spectacular gorges and jagged cliffs.

children.name: a rugged cliff
children.definition: rough and uneven
examples: Huge Atlantic waves were breaking against the rugged cliffs.

children.name: a towering cliff
children.definition: very high
examples: the towering cliffs of Gibraltar

children.name: chalk/limestone/granite cliffs
examples: White chalk cliffs rose up from the sea.

children.name: a cliff face
children.definition: a steep surface or side of a cliff
examples: Some climbers were scrambling up the steep cliff face.

children.name: a cliff edge
examples: Keep away from the cliff edge.

children.name: a cliff top
examples: There was a lovely view from the cliff top.

children.name: a cliff ledge
children.definition: a flat narrow piece that sticks out from a cliff
examples: Some of the goats were even grazing on the cliff ledges.

children.name: a cliff path
examples: I followed the cliff path down to the bay.

children.name: a cliff walk
children.definition: a walk along cliffs
examples: Shall we do the cliff walk this morning?

children.name: be perched
children.definition: high
examples: on a cliff(= be situated on a cliff )An 11th century castle is perched high on the cliff.
